qas.question: Does the halogen bulp increase, reduce, or have no effect on filament evaporation?
How does the halogen bulb decrease darkening over time?

answers.text: by redepositing tungsten from the inside of the bulb back onto the filament

qas.question: Does a halogen bulb operate at a higher or lower temperature than an incandescent?
How does the size of a halogen bulb compare to an incandescent?

answers.text: bulbs are much smaller than normal incandescent bulbs

qas.question: What is the most common situation when a halogen bulb is used?

answers.text: where intense illumination is needed in a limited space

qas.question: What type of bulb increases uneven evaporation?

plausible_answers.text: by redepositing tungsten from the inside of the bulb back onto the filament

qas.question: How does the halogen bulb increase darkening over time?
What type of light can operate at a lower temperature than a standard gas filled lamp?
What type of bulbs are much larger than normal incandescent bulbs?

plausible_answers.text: where intense illumination is needed in a limited space

qas.question: Where are halogen bulbs not widely used?

context: The <b5_0>halogen lamp<b5_0/> <a0_0>reduces<a0_0/> uneven evaporation of the filament and eliminates darkening of the envelope by filling the lamp with a halogen gas at low pressure, rather than an inert gas. The halogen cycle increases the lifetime of the bulb and prevents its darkening <a1_0><b6_0>by redepositing tungsten from the inside of the bulb back onto the filament<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The <b7_0><b8_0>halogen<b8_0/><b7_0/> lamp can operate its filament at a <a2_0>higher<a2_0/> temperature than a standard gas filled lamp of similar power without loss of operating life. Such <a3_0>bulbs are much smaller than normal incandescent bulbs<a3_0/>, and are widely used <a4_0><b9_0>where intense illumination is needed in a limited space<b9_0/><a4_0/>. Fiber-optic lamps for optical microscopy is one typical application.
